\title{Framework and limits on power density in wind and hydrokinetic device arrays using systematic flow manipulation}

\author{Shreyas Mandre and Niall M. Mangan \\  {School of Engineering, Brown University, Providence RI 02912}}






\maketitle

\frenchspacing
\begin{abstract} 
Wind and hydrokinetic turbine array performance suffers because the wakes of upstream turbines diminish flow to downstream turbines. 
Here we analyze systematic deflection of the wakes to direct unimpeded flow onto the downstream turbines and increase the area power density.
We examine the case of an abstract 1D turbine-deflector array aligned parallel to a 2D free stream flow, in which case the array presents negligible frontal area to the flow without deflection.
Using the framework of inviscid fluid dynamics, the flow manipulation is decomposed into flow deflection due to bound vorticity in the array, and energy extraction resulting from free vorticity shed by the array.
While this general framework is agnostic to the technological details, it captures the geometry of a vertical fence of turbines and deflectors along the centerline of a river, minimizing the array footprint.
We find a localized array can direct significant kinetic energy through itself, while having a minimal impact on array efficiency; the fraction of the energy incident on the array that is ultimately extracted.
The maximum array efficiency decreases from ${ 57}\%-{ 39}\%$ at high deflection due to recirculation at the edges of the array.
However, the increase in deflected flow through the array overwhelms the small efficiency decrease.
Using state-of-the-art deflector technology with minimal flow separation, we predict an order of magnitude improvement in array power density, as compared to arrays without systematic flow manipulation.
A pragmatic discussion of deflection mechanisms, applications, and future extension to 3D flows are included.

\end{abstract}





\section{Introduction}

Practical considerations prevent the placement of tidal, riverine, and wind turbines at locations in the flow where they can extract maximum power.
For riverine and tidal power, the hotspots of fast flow occur at narrow constrictions in the channel, and anything less than a complete fence of turbines \cite{Garrett2005} across the flow constriction greatly reduces the potential of the site \cite{Vennell2010, Vennell2011, Cummins2013}. 
However, navigation and environmental considerations prohibit construction of such arrays \cite{Garrett2007,Vennell2015}. 
Similarly, wind turbines cannot be constructed at locations of faster wind speed high up in the atmosphere due to structural constraints \cite{Thresher2007}.


Instead, the most practical arrangement of wind turbines is an array of turbines mounted on the ground in rows, where only turbines at the front of the array have access to direct flow and energy transport to turbines in the center of the array is limited.
Any large riverine or tidal array in this configuration would suffer from the same limitations \cite{Vennell2015,Jeffcoate2016}.
Kinetic energy flowing higher in the atmosphere or the water column is redirected by turbulence on the turbines in the array \cite{Calaf2010,Divett2013}. 
Therefore, subsequent rows of turbines must be placed far enough back for turbulent mixing to redirect kinetic energy from higher elevations to replenish the deficit in the turbine wakes \cite{Newman1977,Frandsen1992}. 
The rate of kinetic energy redirection ultimately limits the performance of the turbine array, and approaches to relax this limit are actively sought \cite{Dabiri2011a,Wagenaar2012,Fleming2014,VerHulst2015,Churchfield2015}.

If turbines must be placed in practical locations, the objective can be reframed as directing more kinetic energy to the turbines and extracting it.  
Here we present a framework for systematic flow manipulation to redirect flow kinetic energy to the location of the turbines. 

We illustrate our framework using a simple two-dimensional example of a linear array embedded in an infinite domain with uniform freestream flow. 
This analysis is motivated by an unconventional riverine turbine array configuration, one in which the turbines are arranged in a vertical fence along the river centerline as shown in Figure~\ref{fig:Schematic}~(c).
Our results directly apply to the cases for which the presence of the river banks and uneven bottom topography can be ignored.

We find the energy extraction efficiency ${\eta_\text{max}}$  only has a weak dependence on the deflected-flow strength and lies within the range ${ 0.39}-{ 0.57}$.

For the case of the riverine turbine array shown in Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(c), our result corresponds to a dimensional array power density of ${506}$ W/m$^2$ for a 1.5 m/s flow.
Through this work, we not only demonstrate a limit on the energy density of the deflector-turbine array, but also present a framework that can be extended for other cases by incorporating additional constraints, such as boundaries defined by river banks or the ground.

The rest of this paper will be devoted to explaining the mathematical genesis and physical intuition of the limits on ${C_A}$. 
We begin by explaining the fluid dynamics framework for our model based on steady inviscid vorticity dynamics, which provides a natural means of decomposing deflection and energy extraction within the array. 
Next, we use the framework to derive bounds on the array power density as a function of flow deflection. 
We characterize the behavior and relative importance of the deflected-flow strength and array efficiency in terms of two dimensionless parameters: a flow reduction factor and the ratio of the wake velocity to free stream velocity. 

Finally, we discuss possible physical realizations of deflectors, the applications to hydrokinetic energy, and possible future extensions.

\section{Framework: Abstract array in an inviscid flow}

While turbines are generally deployed in discrete arrangements, here we consider an array so dense that their collective influence on the flow may be modeled by employing the continuum limit.
Typically, the frontal area of the turbines is much smaller than the area of the array, and we idealize the array to have negligible (zero) thickness.

Inviscid fluid dynamics governs the essential features of the flow that develops around the turbine array.
We represent the deflection of the fluid by the array as bound vorticity within the array and the turbine energy extraction as a source of free vorticity in the flow surrounding the array.
In the framework of inviscid dynamics the array can only influence the flow through the bound and free vorticity.
Therefore, our framework incorporates the most general manipulation the deflector-turbine array can have on the flow.
Although the geometry is different, the spirit of our work is inspired by Lanchester-Betz-Joukowsky ({LBJ}) analysis; we seek a minimal picture which is useful to guide our intuition and assist with the practical design of turbine arrays. 

We currently neglect other sources of free vorticity, such as the viscous boundary layer around the deflectors, and the influence of unsteadiness, viscosity and turbulence on the dynamics of free vorticity.
Such effects could be incorporated by embedding our framework within a larger computational fluid dynamics model \cite{Calaf2010,Divett2013}.

\subsection{Flow deflection and bound vorticity} 
In our framework, the bound vorticity is a fictitious instrument that represents the effect of the deflector array, and in the most general case is agnostic to the method of fluid deflection. 
It is located inside the array and we use it to impose the fluid flowing through the array at a constant angle ${\alpha}$ relative to freestream, which simulates flow through a dense array of foils at a constant angle of attack ${\alpha}$.
We further consider the deflection to occur in a regime where the boundary layer around the deflector plates remains attached, and therefore the deflectors introduce negligible amount of free vorticity in the flow.

Manipulating the flow with bound vorticity alone, the array cannot extract any energy from the flow.
This result follows from the observation that the velocity field due to bound vorticity alone recovers to its freestream value far downstream (see SI \S 2), as shown in Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(a).
The wake of the array therefore has no kinetic energy deficit, and the array cannot extract any energy.
The bound vorticity, however, deflects fluid at the rate $Q_0$ to flow through the array, and thus implies that kinetic energy is incident on the array at the rate $\rho Q_0 U^2/2$

This energy can be extracted from the flow by introducing free vorticity.

\subsection{Energy extraction and free vorticity}
In our framework, the free vorticity in the flow is introduced (or shed) by the turbine array, capturing the effects of energy extraction by the turbines on the fluid flow. 
In analogy with the {LBJ}~analysis, we shed vorticity of specified strength from the array along the two streamlines C and D, bounded by the recirculation regions near the array ends, as shown in Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(b).
These streamlines are selected to be the extreme streamlines which pass through the array and continue down-stream (they do not recirculate).
Both the difference in geometry (the streamlines must bend to flow through the array) and the possibility that the extreme streamlines will not be located at the edge of the array differentiate this analysis from {LBJ}.
Once introduced, the free vorticity is advected by the flow along the streamlines in the form of a vortex sheet without any change in its strength, in accordance with inviscid fluid dynamics \cite{Saffman1992,Lighthill1986}, and forms the wake of the array.
We numerically determine the streamlines, the bound vorticity, and the shape of the free vortex sheet in a self-consistent manner such that the free vorticity is constant along the streamlines and the flow velocity maintains an angle of attack ${\alpha}$ with the freestream flow direction (see SI \S 4 for details).

The free vorticity introduced by the turbine array is linked to the energy conversion.
The wake velocity far downstream, as shown in Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(b), points in the freestream direction, but its magnitude $V$ does not recover to the freestream value $U$.
The deficit of velocity in the wake $U-V$ is, by definition, the strength of the vortex sheet.

\subsection{Deflected-flow strength}

The bound vorticity acts to deflect the fluid so that it flows through the array at a constant angle ${\alpha}$.
We assume that a constant ${\alpha}$ over the length of the array may be achieved in practice using a sufficiently large density of deflector surfaces or orienting them at spatially varying angles of attack.
In the absence of free vorticity, the resulting flow field can be derived analytically for a given ${\alpha}$ using standard techniques in complex analysis (which we include in the SI \S 3 for completeness).
The accompanying bound vorticity is

This dependence has two asymptotic limits; for $\tan {\alpha}\ll 1$, or the weak deflection limit, $Q_0/UL \approx \tan{\alpha}$ and for $\tan {\alpha} \gg 1,$ or the strong deflection limit, $Q_0/UL \approx \sqrt{\tan{\alpha}}$.
These limits may be understood by considering the following: The flow rate $Q_0$, is set by the product of the velocity component normal to the array, $U\tan{\alpha}$, and the length $\ell_0$ of the region between the recirculation zones, $Q_0= U\ell_0 \tan{\alpha} $.
The size of the recirculation region overlapping with the array is characterized in detail in the SI \S 5.
For weak deflection, the recirculation regions are small, and consequently $\ell_0 \approx L$. 
While for strong  deflection, the recirculation region occupies almost all of the array length leading to $\ell_0 \approx L/\sqrt{\tan{\alpha}}$.
These two asymptotes are also shown in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}~(a).
The dependence of the deflected-flow strength on ${\alpha}$, and the direct proportionality between ${C_A}$ and the deflected-flow strength in {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ca}}}}, ultimately determines the predominant behavior of ${C_A}$ as a function of ${\alpha}$ shown Figure~\ref{fig:Schematic}~(d).

In our configuration, the flow reduction occurs for two reasons.
The first is due to resistance offered to the flow by the turbine array, which causes more fluid to flow around the turbine array.
As resistance from the actuator disk is the cause of flow reduction in the {LBJ}~analysis, we expect the quantitative contribution of this mechanism of flow reduction to be the similar.
In the {LBJ}~analysis the flow reduction is $Q/Q_0 = \frac{1}{2}\left(1+V/U\right)$, plotted as a dashed black line in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}~(b).

We implicitly neglect any losses due to the space between individual turbines.
Indeed the expected flow reduction for our array at the weak deflection limit, the uppermost red line plotted in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}, is close (but not identical) to the {LBJ}~line.
This similarity between our flow reduction factor and that of {LBJ}, arises from the similarity of our procedure for determining efficiency using an energy balance on a volume defined by two streamlines shedding vorticity.

The second reason for flow reduction is the development of recirculation regions at the edges of the array.
A detailed characterization of the size of the recirculation regions is presented in SI \S 5.
As the recirculation regions are small but finite in the limit of weak deflection, the flow reduction factor, $Q/Q_0$ differs only slightly from the {LBJ}~case (the difference between the red and black lines).
In the case of strong deflection, the influence of the turbine array resistance on size of the recirculation regions is stronger. 
Therefore, the flow through the array is lower than the {LBJ}~case (lines of increasing blue intensity in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}~(b)).

The dependence of the array efficiency $\eta$ on $V/U$ is also plotted in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}~(b).

Because of its direct relationship with the flow reduction factor (i.e., {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:arrayeff}}}}), both $\eta$ and ${\eta_\text{max}}$ also lie between weak and strong deflection limits.
The upper bound corresponds to the weak deflection limit, in which case ${\eta_\text{max}}\approx { 0.57}$ occurs for $V/U=0.38$, close to the values derived from {LBJ}~analysis. 
The lower bound corresponds to the strong deflection limit, in which case ${\eta_\text{max}} \approx { 0.39}$ occurs for $V/U=0.59$.
The reduction is efficiency in the strong deflection limit may be traced back to a smaller flow reduction factor $Q/Q_0$ for this case, which in turn arises from the increase in size of the recirculation zones due to resistance to the flow offered by the turbines.
In summary, deflecting more flow through the array slightly decreases the efficiency of the array at extracting the impinging energy.

A bound on the array power density can be obtained by recognizing that, by definition, $\eta \le {\eta_\text{max}}$, and which upon substitution into {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ca}}}} leads to {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ourlimit}}}}.


\section{Discussion}
\subsection{Increase in deflected-flow strength outweighs drop in turbine efficiency}

The array power density in {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ourlimit}}}} has opposing dependences on the flow deflection and turbine efficiency. 
On one hand, the maximum possible efficiency of energy conversion, shown in the inset of Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}~(a), decreases with the deflected-flow strength.
But on the other hand, the stronger the deflected flow, the more kinetic energy impinges on the turbines in the array.
Array power density is effected more strongly by the order of magnitude increase of impinging kinetic energy due to deflection than the decrease in array efficiency from  ${ 0.57}$  to ${ 0.39}$.
Therefore, larger array power densities are possible if the bound vorticity in the deflector-turbine array can be reinforced and greater flow deflected, without influencing the free vorticity.
In other words, an optimal value for the deflected-flow strength does not emerge as part of our analysis; 
the greater the deflected-flow strength without flow separation, the higher can the array power density be.


\subsection{Methods for flow deflection} 

Our results, because of their basis in vorticity dynamics, are agnostic to the specific deflecting and energy converting mechanisms employed in the array.
For manipulating the flow, the most obvious candidates we present is an array of airfoil-shaped deflector plates interspersed with the turbines. 
A host of other techniques, such as turbines oriented at an angle to the flow \cite{Wagenaar2012,Fleming2014,Churchfield2015}, or foils oscillating asymmetrically about their mean positions, to vector its wake at an angle to the free stream are conceivable.
The underlying essential principle is that the turbine array introduce the appropriate bound and free vorticity.

{Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ourlimit}}}} shows that the bound on array power density depends on the ability of the array to deflect the flow with minimal introduction of free vorticity.
High-lift aerodynamic surfaces are ideal candidates for this purpose because they are designed to introduce the highest bound vorticity in the flow without significant flow separation.
These surfaces can lead to a lift coefficient of up to 4.5 \cite{Smith1973,Liebeck1978,Lin1997}, which implies bound vorticity equivalent to a flat plate at an approximately 40$^\circ$ angle of attack.
Using these as reference deflectors to estimate the maximum array energy density that can be realized with current technology, we substitute $\alpha=40^\circ$ in {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ourlimit}}}} and obtain ${C_A} = { 0.30}$.
This result is plotted in Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(d).









\subsection{Applications to hydrokinetic power}
One of the direct applications of our approach is an unconventional configuration for tidal and riverine turbine arrays -- 
one in a vertical plane oriented parallel to the flow as shown in Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(c).
In a water stream with 1.5 m/s flow speed, our estimate for the dimensional array energy density is ${506}$ W/m$^2$ (${C_A}=0.3$) compared to 4.6 W/m$^2$ (${C_A}=2.7 \times 10^{-3}$) arising from turbulent mixing in a large conventional array, or 20 W/m$^2$ arising in smaller arrays (${C_A} = 1.2 \times 10^{-2}$).



In addition to the higher energy density, the unconventional configuration offers several practical advantages.
The array makes efficient use of the space, by allowing other uses of the water body and keeping navigational channels open.
Equally importantly, this configuration allows turbines to span the whole depth of the water column.
This possibility implies that only turbine blades or hydrofoils need to be submerged under water, and other mechanical and electrical components may be housed above the surface of water. Operating the drive-train, generators, and interconnecting cables above water reduces the initial installation costs by eliminating the need for marinization, and the operations and maintenance cost by providing easy access.
While a detailed techno-economic analysis is beyond the scope of this article, the results presented here provide an integral component needed to perform cost-benefit analysis of incorporating flow deflection in hydrokinetic turbine arrays. 

In our analysis, we have ignored the presence of any boundaries on the fluid domain, due to the simplicity it provides for analysis and our focus on the essential principles.
For an array length comparable with the channel width, the presence of boundaries will influence the flow and the performance of the array.
However, for arrays shorter than channel width, the influence of the boundaries can be neglected, and our analysis is applicable.
The neglect of boundaries is not a fundamental limitation of our approach or our analysis.
Boundaries can be incorporated using the method of images or boundary integral methods for potential flow to obtain improved bounds and to better design the array.














\subsection{Possible extensions and future directions}
The extension of our framework to three-dimensional flows requires incorporating the more general vorticity dynamics.
Just as lifting line theory for three-dimensional wings is based on the two-dimensional Kutta-Joukowsky relation between bound vorticity and airfoil lift, our results in two dimensions provide the foundation for such an extension to three dimensions.
Furthermore, unsteadiness and turbulence in the flow, the role of fluid viscosity, presence of shear in the freestream, the presence of ground and other boundaries, and the discrete nature of the array will reduce the performance below the limits we present here.
We have also not accounted for gravity, the free interface, and bed friction for the hydrokinetic application.
As can be seen from Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(d), a $5^\circ$ deflection of the flow leads to equal or greater ${C_A}$ than due to turbulent mixing.
Therefore, we expect the influence of deflection greater than $5^\circ$ to overwhelm the influence of turbulence.
These effects could be examined more carefully by embedding the deflector-turbine array in a larger computational fluid dynamics model and through controlled experiments.

\section{Conclusion}
We presented systematic flow manipulation as a strategy to deflect untapped kinetic energy towards a device array consisting of flow deflectors and turbines.
We use the framework of inviscid fluid dynamics to decompose the effects of array on fluid flow into deflection, captured in bound vorticity, and energy extraction, captured by shed vorticity. 
The results calculated here represent upper bounds on performance that are agnostic to the specific technology at the array.

Using the array to impose deflection on the fluid flow can provide an order of magnitude increase in array power density from that achieved by existing arrays.
The large gain in kinetic energy deflected onto the array (deflected-flow strength) outweighs the small decrease in array's efficiency at extracting that energy (from { 57}\% - { 39}\%) due to increased recirculation.
We expect the essential ingredients of this analysis to inform more complicated methods of flow deflection and three-dimensional situations.

Future investigations building on this analysis will help evaluate the technical and economic feasibility of this approach.

\centerline{\LARGE \textbf{Supplementary Information}}
\section{1. ${C_A}$ induced by turbulent mixing}
In this section, we present the details for calculating the equivalent ${C_A}$ from analyses presented in the literature.
These results are summarized in Table~\textbf{SI.1} and plotted in Figure~\ref{fig:Schematic} of the article.
All estimates pertained to arrays of wind turbines, therefore the density of the fluid ranged from $\rho=1.1-1.2$ kg/m$^3$ depending on the source.

\noindent
{\bf a. Calaf, et al, (2010)} \cite{Calaf2010}:
The article simulates the fully developed wind turbine atmospheric boundary layer for pressure-gradient-driven flow around a rectangular array of turbines.
Periodic boundary conditions in both streamwise and spanwise direction imply simulation of an infinite array. 
The turbines are modeled as actuator disks.
The spacing between turbines is 7.85 diameters in the streamwise and 5.23 in the spanwise direction.
The power extracted by the turbines per unit ground area is presented in terms of the friction velocity $u_*$ to be ${\dot{W}}/{A_\text{array}}=4.93/\rho u_*^3$.
The wind speed at hub height in the absence of the turbines is $U=$17.3$u_*$, and it varied from 15.9$u_*$ to 18.8$u_*$ over the actuator disk diameter.
Based on this data, the mean ${C_A}$ is calculated to be $1.9 \times 10^{-3}$. 
The error in this estimate arises due to the variation of the wind speed over the actuator disk.
Using the extremes of the wind speed the range of ${C_A}$ is estimated to be between $1.5 \times 10^{-3}$ and $2.4 \times 10^{-3}$.

{\bf b. Miller, et al, (2015)} \cite{Miller2015}: 
The article simulates atmospheric flow on the national scale in the presence of wind turbines over 112,320 km$^2$ in Kansas. 
They report a maximum vertical kinetic energy flux of 1.1 W/m$^2$ over a region of the wind farm away from the edges with a first to third quantile variation from 0.375 W/m$^2$ to 1.55 W/m$^2$.
They postulate that their results are independent of the size of the farm, and therefore this kinetic energy flux represents the limit on the power conversion by the wind turbines.
The distribution of mean wind speed at hub height is reported, and can be closely approximated by a normal distribution with mean $\mu=8$ m/s and standard deviation $\sigma=2.9$ m/s.
We use this distribution to determine the distribution of $U^3$, which enters the definition of ${C_A}$.
The mean $U^3$, where $U$ is a normally distributed random variable is $\mu^3 + 3 \mu \sigma^2$ = 714 m$^3$/s$^3$.
Based on this information, we estimate ${C_A} = 2.7 \times 10^{-3}$ using the mean values.
We also remark that, in addition to turbulent transport, detailed atmospheric dynamics on the national scale were part of this simulation. 
Parameters such as the wind speed at hub height varied with time, and so did the power production. 

\noindent
{\bf c. Cal, et al, (2010)} \cite{Cal2010}:
The article presents results from a wind-tunnel experiment simulating a $3\times 3 $ array of wind turbines. 
They report the vertical flux of kinetic energy, however, the array may not be large enough to simulate a fully developed boundary layer.
The wind speed, in the absence of energy conversion, at hub height was maintained at 7 m/s, and varied between 6.2 m/s and 7.3 m/s across the rotor diameter.
Using the vertical kinetic energy flux in to the array, and ignoring the power production by the turbines in the front of the array facilitates a quantification of the redirected kinetic energy flux that replenishes the wake deficit.
Because of the small size of the array, this case provides insight into any departure of the kinetic energy redirection from the fully developed cases described in the previous two cases.
A vertical kinetic energy flux of 1.8 W/m$^2$ was estimated using particle image velocimetry. 
Based on this information, we estimate the mean ${C_A}=8.89 \times 10^{-3}$, and using the variation of the wind speed across the rotor derive a range for ${C_A}$ from $8.0\times 10^{-3}$ to $1.3 \times 10^{-2}$.

\noindent
{\bf d. Kinzel, et al, (2012)} \cite{Kinzel2012a}:
The article reports results from a vertical axis wind turbine array with 9 pairs of counter-rotating turbines arranged in a $3\times 3$ array installed in the field.
Flow within and around the array was characterized using ultrasonic anemometers placed at various locations in the array.
The mean wind speed above the turbines is reported to be 8.05 m/s (no information about the variation of this quantity was reported).
The authors report a vertical kinetic energy flux that varies from 2.2 W/m$^2$ at the front of the array to 3.4 W/m$^2$ near the back of the array.
Based on this information, we estimate ${C_A}$ to be in the range from $7.1 \times 10^{-3}$ $1.1 \times 10^{-2}$ with a mean value of $9.09 \times 10^{-3}$.

\noindent
{\bf e. MacKay (2008)} \cite{Mackay2008}:
The book reports and uses a simplified analysis where each horizontal axis turbine of diameter $D$ occupies an area of $5D \times 5D$ is a square array.
The turbine operates at 50\% efficiency extracting $\frac{1}{2} (\frac{1}{2} \rho U^3 \pi D^2/4)$, which based on the ground area of ${A_\text{array}} = 25 D^2$ yields  ${C_A} = \pi/200 = 1.57 \times 10^{-2}$.
Despite the simplified nature of this analysis, given that no wind turbine array has considered installing turbine closer than $5D$, the estimate provides useful bound and insight into the origin of the small magnitude of ${C_A}$.

{\bf a. Churchfield, et al, (2015)} \cite{Churchfield2015}:
The article reports results from a computational investigation of five wind turbines installed in a straight line along the prevailing wind direction. 
Each turbine is 115 m is diameter, and the inter-turbine separation is 1008 m, which implies a ground plane \emph{or} vertical area of $4\times 1008 \text{ m} \times 115 \text{ m}= 463,680 \text{ m}^2$ .
We use this area as our reference area.
They simulate turbines pointing directly into, as well as yawed 5$^\circ$, 15$^\circ$, and 25$^\circ$ to the wind. 

The wind speed at hub height is 9 m/s, and the first (unwaked) turbine generates 1.87 MW. 
They report that in the un-yawed configuration, the turbine farm generates 59.7\% of the power five independent unwaked turbines would generate, which implies a total production of 5.58 MW.
In this configuration, ${C_A} = 2.87 \times 10^{-2}$.

This increases ${C_A}$ to ${C_A} = 3.10 \times 10^{-2}$.

We use a consistent color scheme in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower} to represent weak and strong deflection limits in red and blue respectively.

In our configuration, the flow reduction occurs for two reasons.
The first is due to resistance offered to the flow by the turbine array, which causes more fluid to flow around the turbine array.
As resistance from the actuator disk is the cause of flow reduction in the {LBJ}~analysis, we expect the quantitative contribution of this mechanism of flow reduction to be the similar.
In the {LBJ}~analysis the flow reduction is $Q/Q_0 = \frac{1}{2}\left(1+V/U\right)$, plotted as a dashed black line in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}~(b).

We implicitly neglect any losses due to the space between individual turbines.
Indeed the expected flow reduction for our array at the weak deflection limit, the uppermost red line plotted in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}, is close (but not identical) to the {LBJ}~line.
This similarity between our flow reduction factor and that of {LBJ}, arises from the similarity of our procedure for determining efficiency using an energy balance on a volume defined by two streamlines shedding vorticity.

The second reason for flow reduction is the development of recirculation regions at the edges of the array.
A detailed characterization of the size of the recirculation regions is presented in SI \S 5.
As the recirculation regions are small but finite in the limit of weak deflection, the flow reduction factor, $Q/Q_0$ differs only slightly from the {LBJ}~case (the difference between the red and black lines).
In the case of strong deflection, the influence of the turbine array resistance on size of the recirculation regions is stronger. 
Therefore, the flow through the array is lower than the {LBJ}~case (lines of increasing blue intensity in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}~(b)).

The dependence of the array efficiency $\eta$ on $V/U$ is also plotted in Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}~(b). 
A maximum $\eta$ for fixed $Q_0/UL$ arises as we vary $V/U$ due to a competition between the increasing wake deficit and decreasing flow, which is defined as

Because of its direct relationship with the flow reduction factor (i.e., {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:arrayeff}}}}), both $\eta$ and ${\eta_\text{max}}$ also lie between weak and strong deflection limits.
The upper bound corresponds to the weak deflection limit, in which case ${\eta_\text{max}}\approx { 0.57}$ occurs for $V/U=0.38$, close to the values derived from {LBJ}~analysis. 
The lower bound corresponds to the strong deflection limit, in which case ${\eta_\text{max}} \approx { 0.39}$ occurs for $V/U=0.59$.
The reduction is efficiency in the strong deflection limit may be traced back to a smaller flow reduction factor $Q/Q_0$ for this case, which in turn arises from the increase in size of the recirculation zones due to resistance to the flow offered by the turbines.
In summary, deflecting more flow through the array slightly decreases the efficiency of the array at extracting the impinging energy.

A bound on the array power density can be obtained by recognizing that, by definition, $\eta \le {\eta_\text{max}}$, and which upon substitution into {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ca}}}} leads to {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ourlimit}}}}.


\section{Discussion}
\subsection{Increase in deflected-flow strength outweighs drop in turbine efficiency}

The array power density in {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ourlimit}}}} has opposing dependences on the flow deflection and turbine efficiency. 
On one hand, the maximum possible efficiency of energy conversion, shown in the inset of Figure \ref{fig:FlowPower}~(a), decreases with the deflected-flow strength.
But on the other hand, the stronger the deflected flow, the more kinetic energy impinges on the turbines in the array.
Array power density is effected more strongly by the order of magnitude increase of impinging kinetic energy due to deflection than the decrease in array efficiency from  ${ 0.57}$  to ${ 0.39}$.
Therefore, larger array power densities are possible if the bound vorticity in the deflector-turbine array can be reinforced and greater flow deflected, without influencing the free vorticity.
In other words, an optimal value for the deflected-flow strength does not emerge as part of our analysis; 
the greater the deflected-flow strength without flow separation, the higher can the array power density be.


\subsection{Methods for flow deflection} 

Our results, because of their basis in vorticity dynamics, are agnostic to the specific deflecting and energy converting mechanisms employed in the array.
For manipulating the flow, the most obvious candidates we present is an array of airfoil-shaped deflector plates interspersed with the turbines. 
A host of other techniques, such as turbines oriented at an angle to the flow \cite{Wagenaar2012,Fleming2014,Churchfield2015}, or foils oscillating asymmetrically about their mean positions, to vector its wake at an angle to the free stream are conceivable.
The underlying essential principle is that the turbine array introduce the appropriate bound and free vorticity.

{Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ourlimit}}}} shows that the bound on array power density depends on the ability of the array to deflect the flow with minimal introduction of free vorticity.
High-lift aerodynamic surfaces are ideal candidates for this purpose because they are designed to introduce the highest bound vorticity in the flow without significant flow separation.
These surfaces can lead to a lift coefficient of up to 4.5 \cite{Smith1973,Liebeck1978,Lin1997}, which implies bound vorticity equivalent to a flat plate at an approximately 40$^\circ$ angle of attack.
Using these as reference deflectors to estimate the maximum array energy density that can be realized with current technology, we substitute $\alpha=40^\circ$ in {Eq.~\textbf{\ref{{eqn:ourlimit}}}} and obtain ${C_A} = { 0.30}$.
This result is plotted in Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(d).









\subsection{Applications to hydrokinetic power}
One of the direct applications of our approach is an unconventional configuration for tidal and riverine turbine arrays -- 
one in a vertical plane oriented parallel to the flow as shown in Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(c).
In a water stream with 1.5 m/s flow speed, our estimate for the dimensional array energy density is ${506}$ W/m$^2$ (${C_A}=0.3$) compared to 4.6 W/m$^2$ (${C_A}=2.7 \times 10^{-3}$) arising from turbulent mixing in a large conventional array, or 20 W/m$^2$ arising in smaller arrays (${C_A} = 1.2 \times 10^{-2}$).



In addition to the higher energy density, the unconventional configuration offers several practical advantages.
The array makes efficient use of the space, by allowing other uses of the water body and keeping navigational channels open.
Equally importantly, this configuration allows turbines to span the whole depth of the water column.
This possibility implies that only turbine blades or hydrofoils need to be submerged under water, and other mechanical and electrical components may be housed above the surface of water. Operating the drive-train, generators, and interconnecting cables above water reduces the initial installation costs by eliminating the need for marinization, and the operations and maintenance cost by providing easy access.
While a detailed techno-economic analysis is beyond the scope of this article, the results presented here provide an integral component needed to perform cost-benefit analysis of incorporating flow deflection in hydrokinetic turbine arrays. 

In our analysis, we have ignored the presence of any boundaries on the fluid domain, due to the simplicity it provides for analysis and our focus on the essential principles.
For an array length comparable with the channel width, the presence of boundaries will influence the flow and the performance of the array.
However, for arrays shorter than channel width, the influence of the boundaries can be neglected, and our analysis is applicable.
The neglect of boundaries is not a fundamental limitation of our approach or our analysis.
Boundaries can be incorporated using the method of images or boundary integral methods for potential flow to obtain improved bounds and to better design the array.














\subsection{Possible extensions and future directions}
The extension of our framework to three-dimensional flows requires incorporating the more general vorticity dynamics.
Just as lifting line theory for three-dimensional wings is based on the two-dimensional Kutta-Joukowsky relation between bound vorticity and airfoil lift, our results in two dimensions provide the foundation for such an extension to three dimensions.
Furthermore, unsteadiness and turbulence in the flow, the role of fluid viscosity, presence of shear in the freestream, the presence of ground and other boundaries, and the discrete nature of the array will reduce the performance below the limits we present here.
We have also not accounted for gravity, the free interface, and bed friction for the hydrokinetic application.
As can be seen from Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(d), a $5^\circ$ deflection of the flow leads to equal or greater ${C_A}$ than due to turbulent mixing.
Therefore, we expect the influence of deflection greater than $5^\circ$ to overwhelm the influence of turbulence.
These effects could be examined more carefully by embedding the deflector-turbine array in a larger computational fluid dynamics model and through controlled experiments.

\section{Conclusion}
We presented systematic flow manipulation as a strategy to deflect untapped kinetic energy towards a device array consisting of flow deflectors and turbines.
We use the framework of inviscid fluid dynamics to decompose the effects of array on fluid flow into deflection, captured in bound vorticity, and energy extraction, captured by shed vorticity. 
The results calculated here represent upper bounds on performance that are agnostic to the specific technology at the array.

Using the array to impose deflection on the fluid flow can provide an order of magnitude increase in array power density from that achieved by existing arrays.
The large gain in kinetic energy deflected onto the array (deflected-flow strength) outweighs the small decrease in array's efficiency at extracting that energy (from { 57}\% - { 39}\%) due to increased recirculation.
We expect the essential ingredients of this analysis to inform more complicated methods of flow deflection and three-dimensional situations.

Future investigations building on this analysis will help evaluate the technical and economic feasibility of this approach.

\section{1. ${C_A}$ induced by turbulent mixing}
In this section, we present the details for calculating the equivalent ${C_A}$ from analyses presented in the literature.
These results are summarized in Table~\textbf{SI.1} and plotted in Figure~\ref{fig:Schematic} of the article.
All estimates pertained to arrays of wind turbines, therefore the density of the fluid ranged from $\rho=1.1-1.2$ kg/m$^3$ depending on the source.

\noindent
{\bf a. Calaf, et al, (2010)} \cite{Calaf2010}:
The article simulates the fully developed wind turbine atmospheric boundary layer for pressure-gradient-driven flow around a rectangular array of turbines.
Periodic boundary conditions in both streamwise and spanwise direction imply simulation of an infinite array. 
The turbines are modeled as actuator disks.
The spacing between turbines is 7.85 diameters in the streamwise and 5.23 in the spanwise direction.
The power extracted by the turbines per unit ground area is presented in terms of the friction velocity $u_*$ to be ${\dot{W}}/{A_\text{array}}=4.93/\rho u_*^3$.
The wind speed at hub height in the absence of the turbines is $U=$17.3$u_*$, and it varied from 15.9$u_*$ to 18.8$u_*$ over the actuator disk diameter.
Based on this data, the mean ${C_A}$ is calculated to be $1.9 \times 10^{-3}$. 
The error in this estimate arises due to the variation of the wind speed over the actuator disk.
Using the extremes of the wind speed the range of ${C_A}$ is estimated to be between $1.5 \times 10^{-3}$ and $2.4 \times 10^{-3}$.

{\bf b. Miller, et al, (2015)} \cite{Miller2015}: 
The article simulates atmospheric flow on the national scale in the presence of wind turbines over 112,320 km$^2$ in Kansas. 
They report a maximum vertical kinetic energy flux of 1.1 W/m$^2$ over a region of the wind farm away from the edges with a first to third quantile variation from 0.375 W/m$^2$ to 1.55 W/m$^2$.
They postulate that their results are independent of the size of the farm, and therefore this kinetic energy flux represents the limit on the power conversion by the wind turbines.
The distribution of mean wind speed at hub height is reported, and can be closely approximated by a normal distribution with mean $\mu=8$ m/s and standard deviation $\sigma=2.9$ m/s.
We use this distribution to determine the distribution of $U^3$, which enters the definition of ${C_A}$.
The mean $U^3$, where $U$ is a normally distributed random variable is $\mu^3 + 3 \mu \sigma^2$ = 714 m$^3$/s$^3$.
Based on this information, we estimate ${C_A} = 2.7 \times 10^{-3}$ using the mean values.
We also remark that, in addition to turbulent transport, detailed atmospheric dynamics on the national scale were part of this simulation. 
Parameters such as the wind speed at hub height varied with time, and so did the power production. 

\noindent
{\bf c. Cal, et al, (2010)} \cite{Cal2010}:
The article presents results from a wind-tunnel experiment simulating a $3\times 3 $ array of wind turbines. 
They report the vertical flux of kinetic energy, however, the array may not be large enough to simulate a fully developed boundary layer.
The wind speed, in the absence of energy conversion, at hub height was maintained at 7 m/s, and varied between 6.2 m/s and 7.3 m/s across the rotor diameter.
Using the vertical kinetic energy flux in to the array, and ignoring the power production by the turbines in the front of the array facilitates a quantification of the redirected kinetic energy flux that replenishes the wake deficit.
Because of the small size of the array, this case provides insight into any departure of the kinetic energy redirection from the fully developed cases described in the previous two cases.
A vertical kinetic energy flux of 1.8 W/m$^2$ was estimated using particle image velocimetry. 
Based on this information, we estimate the mean ${C_A}=8.89 \times 10^{-3}$, and using the variation of the wind speed across the rotor derive a range for ${C_A}$ from $8.0\times 10^{-3}$ to $1.3 \times 10^{-2}$.

\noindent
{\bf d. Kinzel, et al, (2012)} \cite{Kinzel2012a}:
The article reports results from a vertical axis wind turbine array with 9 pairs of counter-rotating turbines arranged in a $3\times 3$ array installed in the field.
Flow within and around the array was characterized using ultrasonic anemometers placed at various locations in the array.
The mean wind speed above the turbines is reported to be 8.05 m/s (no information about the variation of this quantity was reported).
The authors report a vertical kinetic energy flux that varies from 2.2 W/m$^2$ at the front of the array to 3.4 W/m$^2$ near the back of the array.
Based on this information, we estimate ${C_A}$ to be in the range from $7.1 \times 10^{-3}$ $1.1 \times 10^{-2}$ with a mean value of $9.09 \times 10^{-3}$.

\noindent
{\bf e. MacKay (2008)} \cite{Mackay2008}:
The book reports and uses a simplified analysis where each horizontal axis turbine of diameter $D$ occupies an area of $5D \times 5D$ is a square array.
The turbine operates at 50\% efficiency extracting $\frac{1}{2} (\frac{1}{2} \rho U^3 \pi D^2/4)$, which based on the ground area of ${A_\text{array}} = 25 D^2$ yields  ${C_A} = \pi/200 = 1.57 \times 10^{-2}$.
Despite the simplified nature of this analysis, given that no wind turbine array has considered installing turbine closer than $5D$, the estimate provides useful bound and insight into the origin of the small magnitude of ${C_A}$.

An example of the flow field derived using this technique is shown in Figure \ref{fig:Schematic}~(a) of the article. 
The flow develops two recirculation regions centered around the end points of the array $x=\pm L/2$, and the fluid from far upstream is entrained into the array between these regions.
The streamline that bounds the recirculation region forms the separatrix between the flow from the far upstream that does or does not pass through the array.
This separatrix necessarily contains a stagnation point of the flow, the point where the flow velocity is zero.

\section{4. Numerical method}

For a given ${\alpha}$ and $V$, the unknowns describing the flow are the bound and free vorticity distributions.
The bound vorticity is localized to the turbine array $-L/2<x<L/2$, and described as ${\omega_b} = {\omega_{b0}}(x) \delta(y)$.
The free vorticity is represented in the form of sheets of strength $\Omega = (U-V)$ along two streamlines along unknown curves ${\boldsymbol{x}}_n(s)$, $n=1,2$, so ${\omega_f}({\boldsymbol{x}}) = \Omega (\delta({\boldsymbol{x}}-{\boldsymbol{x}}_1) - \delta({\boldsymbol{x}}-{\boldsymbol{x}}_2))$, where $0<s<\infty$ parametrizes the curves.

The bound vorticity ${\omega_{b0}}(x'_k)$ is chosen such that $v = u \tan {\alpha}$ at ${\boldsymbol{x}}=x'_k {\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}}$.
This criteria does not uniquely determine the bound vorticity distribution but instead leads to a one-parameter family. 
This characteristic is analogous to the arbitrariness of the net circulation in thin airfoil theory; an amount $K/\sqrt{L^2/4-x^2}$ added to the bound vorticity for arbitrary $K$ does not change the flow direction at the deflector array.
We choose the $K$ which leads to zero circulation in the far-field; our results are insensitive to other choices of $K$.

nexttext:
The constant is chosen using a bisection algorithm by detecting whether the streamlines form closed contours or extend to far downstream to determine streamlines bounded by the recirculation region at the turbine array ends.
A fractional update ${\boldsymbol{x}}_n^{q+1} = \theta \tilde{{\boldsymbol{x}}}_n^{q+1} +(1-\theta) {\boldsymbol{x}}_n^q$, with $0<\theta \le 1$, is used to ensure convergence.


\section{5. Length of the recirculation region}
In this section, we provide more details about dependence of the length of the recirculation region on the flow parameters. 
Results from our numerical solutions characterizing this length is presented in figure \ref{fig:Recirc}.
The quantity of interest is the length, $\ell_0$ without energy extraction and $\ell$ with energy extraction, of the segment on the array between the two recirculation regions. 
Figure \ref{fig:Recirc}~(a) shows the dependence of the length of the array occupied by the recirculation region scaled by the array length.

Based on this relation, the two asymptotic limits may be deduced.
In the limit of weak deflection, $\ell_0/L \approx 1-\tan^2\alpha/2$, and in the limit of strong deflection $\ell_0/L \approx 1/\sqrt{\tan{\alpha}}$. 
These asymptotes are also shown in Figure \ref{fig:Recirc}~(a).

For wake speed less than the free stream, the recirculation region grows, and consequently $\ell$ is smaller than $\ell_0$.
This dependence of $\ell$ on $V/U$ is shown in Figure \ref{fig:Recirc}~(b).
In the weak deflection limit, the recirculation region grows to a small but finite size compared to the array length.
In the strong defection limit, the recirculation region grows and $\ell$ decreases prominently below $\ell_0$. 
This growth in the size of the recirculation region is underlies the quantitative difference between LBJ and our results.


\begin{figure*}
\centerline{\includegraphics[height=55mm]{Figures/Recirc}}
\caption{
Characterization of the length $\ell_0$ without energy conversion and $\ell$ with energy conversion of the region on the turbine between the two recirculation regions. 
(a) The length of array occupied by the recirculation region $L-\ell_0$ scaled by the array length $L$ is plotted as a function of the deflector slope, when the flow is merely deflected but no energy is extracted. 
In the weak deflection limit, the asymptote $\ell_0 \approx L(1- \tan^2{\alpha}/2)$ is also shown. 
In the strong deflection limit, $\ell_0/L \approx 1/\sqrt{\tan {\alpha}}$, and the recirculation region occupies almost the whole length of the array.
(b) The reduction in the length $\ell$ compared to its value, $\ell_0$,  without energy extraction.
As the wake velocity reduces below the free stream value, the size of the recirculation region grows, and the length of the region in between shrinks. 
This reduction is a small but finite in the limit of weak deflection, and the reduction is prominent in the limit of strong deflection.
}
\label{fig:Recirc}
\end{figure*}

The constant is chosen using a bisection algorithm by detecting whether the streamlines form closed contours or extend to far downstream to determine streamlines bounded by the recirculation region at the turbine array ends.
A fractional update ${\boldsymbol{x}}_n^{q+1} = \theta \tilde{{\boldsymbol{x}}}_n^{q+1} +(1-\theta) {\boldsymbol{x}}_n^q$, with $0<\theta \le 1$, is used to ensure convergence.


\section{5. Length of the recirculation region}
In this section, we provide more details about dependence of the length of the recirculation region on the flow parameters. 
Results from our numerical solutions characterizing this length is presented in figure \ref{fig:Recirc}.
The quantity of interest is the length, $\ell_0$ without energy extraction and $\ell$ with energy extraction, of the segment on the array between the two recirculation regions. 
Figure \ref{fig:Recirc}~(a) shows the dependence of the length of the array occupied by the recirculation region scaled by the array length.
